Question: What is a concentration?
Answer: A concentration consists of three advanced 9-unit courses (27 units) and one summative (9-units or equivalent) project course or equivalent advised research experience. Students may substitute an approved minor or second major for a concentration. Usually, a concentration is completed during the 3rd and 4th year of studies.

Question: Available concentrations
Answer: CMU in Qatar offers the following concentrations: Data Science, Digitalization, Information Security and Privacy.

Question: Minors as concentrations
Answer: Approved minors include: Computer Science, Economics, Computational Biology, Technology Entrepreneurship (Only in Qatar), Business Administration. More minors and concentrations are approved at CMU Pittsburgh. Description of the approved minors can be found at: https://scotty.qatar.cmu.edu/minor-information/ and more minors/concentrations at Pittsburgh: https://www.cmu.edu/information-systems/majors-minors-concentrations.html

Question: Approved and available second majors as concentrations
Answer: Only an additional major in Computer Science could substitute a concentration.

Question: Declaration of a concentration
Answer: Students must declare their concentrations through Stellic by the Spring of their sophomore year to guarantee priority in courses. It is recommended to discuss options with an academic advisor. Declaration can be done via: https://academicaudit.andrew.cmu.edu/app/

Question: Declaration of a minor/additional major as a concentration
Answer: Students must declare their minor/additional major no later than the Spring of their sophomore year before registration week.

Question: Course Double counting Policy
Answer: Up to 2 courses may double count with other programs, up to 1 course may double count with minor programs, no limit with Dietrich College General Education courses, but none of the concentration courses may double count with the Technical core, IS core, and IS breadth.

Question: Declaration of a Summative 9-unit project course substitute
Answer: Students must declare the substitution before taking the course and should use the 'IS Summative concentration course substitute' form.

Question: Permitted substitutions for the summative 9-unit project course
Answer: Students can take a senior honors thesis (66-501 and 66-502), or a 9-unit independent study in an approved domain. Independent studies must include an IS faculty supervisor and be pre-approved.

Question: Completion conditions
Answer: Completion of the concentration requires successful completion of all 27 coursework units plus successful completion of the summative course. Corequisite arrangements are possible under exceptional circumstances.
